titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Mark Harwell. Revised by Friederike Baer (NEH 2010).

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:20-0400

did.abstract:
A leading national opinion maker and influential regional politician, tied by marriage to the families of Benjamin Franklin and cognate families, William Duane (1760-1835) played key roles in the field of political journalism, as well as national, Pennsylvania and local Philadelphia politics. Editor of the Aurora, William Duane (1760-1835) assured himself gratitude from Jefferson and the Republicans and enmity from President Adams and the Federalists for his open and effective attacks on Federalist policies. His son William John Duane (1780-1865), was a prominent member of the Pennsylvania legislature, a legal advisor to Stephen Girard, Solicitor for many of Philadelphia's premier institutions, and Secretary of the Treasury of the United States (June-September 1833).
The Duane Family Collection contains a diverse assemblage of personal and professional correspondence relating to family members, with interesting material relating to William Duane (1760-1835), his son, William John Duane (1780-1865), grandson William Duane (1808-1882), great-grandson Charles Williams Duane (1837-1915), and other relations. The collection includes unique correspondence from and relating to Benjamin Franklin's family, as well as correspondence with Thomas Jefferson and other leading figures from the early nineteenth century. The collection also includes prints, photographs of family members, as well as some maps.
did.physloc: LH-MV-E-17; LH-MV-C-9 (OS); LH-MV-D-7 (OS); LH-SB-Black Case-9 (Series V, OS)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: A leading national opinion maker and influential regional politician, tied by marriage to the families of Benjamin Franklin and cognate families, William Duane (1760-1835) played key roles in the field of political journalism, as well as national, Pennsylvania and local Philadelphia politics. Editor of the Aurora, William Duane (1760-1835) assured himself gratitude from Jefferson and the Republicans and enmity from President Adams and the Federalists for his open and effective attacks on Federalist policies. His son William John Duane (1780-1865), was a prominent member of the Pennsylvania legislature, a legal advisor to Stephen Girard, Solicitor for many of Philadelphia's premier institutions, and Treasurer of the United States (June-September 1833).

Born near Lake Champlain, NY in 1760 to John and Anastasia Duane, William Duane was sent to Ireland at the age of eleven to be raised by his mother's family. Receiving a quality education due to his mother's relative wealth, he was nonetheless disinherited upon his marriage to a Protestant. Moving to England for a short time to stay with an uncle and learn the printing business, he then removed to India in 1784 in order establish himself. Starting up a newspaper, The World, in Calcutta, William became quite successful in acquiring increased business and real estate holdings. Falling upon disfavor with the East India Company, he was subsequently kidnapped and involuntarily shipped back to England. Failing redress in compensation from the East India Company or Parliament, he decided to become a reporter on Parliament for a journal which ultimately became the London Times. Returning to America in 1795, William began work for the Aurora, a paper established by Benjamin Franklin Bache. William took over the editorship in of the Aurora in 1798 upon Bache's death, and transformed the Aurora from a local Republican paper into a state and national political organ. A partisan publication, the Aurora under William Duane became even more heavily associated with Jeffersonian politics and a thorn in the Federalists side. William became the focus of President Adams ire, with his ridicule of the Alien and Sedition Acts generating a great deal of hostile attention. Often openly physically attacked by Federalist sympathizers, he persevered and was credited by Jefferson with securing Pennsylvania and therefore the Presidency for him. William became heavily influential in Pennsylvania state politics, with the ability to determine the nomination of at least two Pennsylvania governors. With the War of 1812, William was appointed U. S. Adjutant General with the rank of Colonel. In 1822, he sold the Aurora and entered a new phase in his life. William traveled throughout South America in 1822, developing contacts, and surveying the political situation. Upon his return, he was appointed prothonotary of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania for the eastern district, a post he retained until his death in 1835.

A politician of some regional prominence and briefly a member of Andrew Jackson's cabinet, William John Duane (1780-1865) was an influential figure in both national and Pennsylvania politics. Beginning his career working for his father William Duane (1760-1835) at the Aurora, William John Duane then managed a bookstore and printing business in the nation's new capital, Washington, D. C., responsible (along with his father) for printing the Congressional Journal (Senate) 1803-1808. Following his marriage in 1805, he entered the paper business, managing sales. In 1809, he was elected to the Pennsylvania state legislature, a relationship he never entirely removed himself from - even when not in office. With an inheritance from his father-in-law in 1811, he studied law and entered the bar in 1815. William John served as solicitor for many of Philadelphia's institutions, including the Carpenters' Company, as well as legal advisor to Stephan Girard. He wrote tracts which were greatly influential to Andrew Jackson's winning of Pennsylvania's vote in the Presidential election of 1828. Offered the mayoralty of Philadelphia, he declined. He was subsequently appointed by Andrew Jackson as one of three commissioners under the treaty with Denmark. William John Duane rejected an appointment by Jackson as U. S. District Attorney, and again rejected an appointment as Director of the Bank of the United States. In 1832 he did agree to accept the appointment as Secretary of the Treasury under Jackson, and assumed the office in June of 1833. Disagreeing with Jackson on the fundamental issue of removing Federal monies from the Bank of the United States (an early pre-cursor to the Federal Reserve), William John Duane spent the next few months attempting to negotiate with Jackson, finally refusing to cooperate, which resulted in his termination as Secretary of the Treasury on September 23, 1833. Upon his return to Philadelphia, William John Duane fell back on a limited private practice of law, supplemented by monies he had previously set aside. He became one of the Directors of Girard College for a term of office, and subsequently retired from public life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Duane Family Collection contains personal papers, correspondence, notes, printed materials, prints, photographs, and glass slides that have derived from and are related to generations of the Duane family. At the core of the collection, is a selection of personal and professional correspondence relating to William Duane (1760-1835), his son, William John Duane (1780-1865), grandson William Duane (1808-1882), and great-grandson Charles Williams Duane (1837-1915).

The materials relating to the Duane family include William Duane's (1760-1835) correspondence with Colonial British officials, as well as personages such as Thomas Jefferson, and prominent men in the Pennsylvania legislature. Of general note is correspondence relating to Revolutionary French officials taking over Caribbean islands, correspondence relating to Benjamin Franklin, an 1806 letter from Andrew Jackson, and later correspondence (William John Duane 1780-1865) to and from President Andrew Jackson.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Duane Family Collection, American Philosophical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The American Philosophical Society Library's catalog lists 23 items related to the Duane Family, or individual family members. Included in our manuscript collections is the Castle Bach Collection, and a large number of collections relating to Benjamin Franklin.
Other related major manuscript collections are held at the John Stevens Collection, National Museum of American History; and the Peter Force Library, Library of Congress.
The APS has a partial run of the newspaper, the Aurora.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: A collection of all the laws of the province of Pennsylvania (Philadelphia: Benjamin Franklin, 1742).
Duane, Morris, Duane, Morris & Heckscher (Philadelphia : Printed for the firm only, 1979). 340.0973 D85d
Merrill, John Houston, Memoranda relating to the Mifflin family (Philadelphia: privately printed, 1890).

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: The Duane Family Collection is a rich and diverse collection that includes papers from numerous prominent citizens from the colonial era to the antebellum period. The bulk of the collection is from 1800-1840. These letters often touch on political affairs as they relate to Duane’s editorship of the Aurora. Also of particular note, the collection contains a series of letters on early national politics with some significant presidential correspondence. There are also family letters between William John Duane’s son, also named William Duane, and his sisters Mary and Sarah Duane that discusses social events, courtship, and gossip about individuals, including details on the deaths of two of Duane’s friends in a duel. Some of the early documents (before 1800) include records of Duane’s newspaper business in India, where he operated in the 1790s as a dissenting voice against the East India Company’s policies.

Perhaps because of William Duane’s connection to the Aurora, there are a series of Franklin family letters from the colonial and revolutionary eras. Also because of Duane’s prominence as a newspaperman, there is a range of other letters, including some from very prominent figures (Andrew Jackson, Stephen Girard, Thomas Jefferson, John Quincy Adams, Henry Clay) in the early republic. Many of the letters that Duane received touch upon important issues of the day. Indeed, some appear to be written as dispatches meant to appear in Duane’s newspaper. Topics of letters Duane received include reports on India, the French Revolution, trade, Jefferson’s election, diplomacy, and other world affairs. The letters to the editor that survive in this collection also offer insight into the workings of the early national press and reporting.

Of particular note, the collection contains a series of Andrew Jackson letters ranging from 1806 to 1833 (bulk 1830s) that often discuss politics. The 1806 letter discusses Jackson’s financial straits because he lost four slave ships, which put him in arrears. Letters from 1833 to William John Duane, a Jackson-appointed Director of the Bank of the United States and Secretary of the Treasury, describe Jackson’s plans for dismantling the Bank and establishing a “new system.” Duane rejected Jackson’s plans and the correspondence chronicles the tensions between the two men that developed following Duane’s refusal to follow Jackson’s plans. Duane’s defiance ultimately led to his resignation and replacement by Roger Taney.

scopecontent.p: Remnant of letter from Mathew Duane, uncle to William Duane.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains news from home, including a list of items desired from England. Mentions daughter Sally, son William, Mr. Henderson, Mr. Galloway, and Mrs. Stephenson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has met with father (B. Franklin) who received him with "open arms." Mentions hospitality of Mrs. Stevenson and Mrs. Hewson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Instructions to Capt. Cleveland, directing him to sail to France to deliver a sensitive "cargo" to a Mr. Merk? in Bordeaux and receive a new "cargoe" from a Sammuel Delap? Is instucted to contact Silas Deane--political and financial agent in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regards matter of debt owed by Jackson to Preston, regarding shipment of slaves, cotton and whiskey. Jackson claims he is trying to repay debt, "but mortals may strive, but cannot command the gods."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for a job as editor of the Aurora. Challenges Duane to a duel. Mentions trepidation on challenging him due to Duane's status as a Colonel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informs Pike of mediated peace talks with Great Britain. Imparts plans for deployment of troops. Directs him in the deployment of platoons, and implores him to "depend on the bayonet."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to Richard Bache, Mrs. Sarah Bache, and Benjamin Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces a friend, Mr. Hamilton, who has been in South America. Reports the loss of three of his children in the last ten months. News of the divorce of king George IV. Predicts an "explosion" in Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that package aboard Baltimore steam boat be delivered to Mr. Poinsett at Norfolk (VA) or held for later transport to Mexico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family news and advice. Admonishes son to keep practicing the flute, in preparation for a family concert. Mentions purchase of a piano, "the cost of which is considerable," books for his education, and a fur cap.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discusses practice on various musical instruments, new purchases by father of furniture (stool), a new fireplace grate, family news and gossip.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advice on means to a happy life. Counsels son to be more interested in the future than family history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives advice on education for a successful career. Mentions William Duane Jr.'s discontent with various schools, including West Point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal advice on how to lead meaningful life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.p: Critisizes Spannish as a lesser breed of mankind. Asks Duane to recommend a U.S. journal or publication which might publish South American affairs. Mentions theft of his scientific instruments and books, and asks Duane for assistance in replacing them.

scopecontent.p: Jackson directs Duane as Secretary of the Treasury to discontinue the Bank of the United States, and direct (Discretely) the deposits on hand to state banks in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Georgia, South Carolina, and Alabama.

scopecontent.p: Returns the draft of the instruction on the bank closure, with minor edits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advice on Philadelphia politics. Mentions his own situation relating to "mattter of great consequence."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: States that his corrections to his report to Jackson in no way constitutes "no cause for a change of depository" arrangement.

scopecontent.p: Submits report of agents evaluation of whether state banks would submit to federal authority.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal and political news of Washington. Expects to be sent home (dismissed) from his position soon. Advice on how to begin married life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Objects publication (in the Globe) of announcement by Jackson that federal monies would be removed to state banks--befor Duane had issued his approval or rejection of said action.

did.unittitle: AQS, a fair copy, to Andrew Jackson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks Jackson for one day before giving his official decision regarding the Bank of the United States, so as to be able to counsel ("As I have not a friend here to advise with") with his father.

odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. Includes enclosures, 4 separate copies of prior letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends notice that the President requires the paper containing his decision of the deposits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unequivical refusal to move public monies from the Bank of the United States. Cites a summary of events ana correspondence that led to this point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Summary and copies of correspondence Sept. 18-20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clarifies position: that in earlier communication he was not equivicating in his refusal to transfer public monies from the Bank of the United States. Reiterates position, "I refuse to aid, assist, or in any way participate in the proposed changes..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note accompanying letter sent day prior (backdated). Mentions his father's proofreading and consultations regarding matter of decision regarding Duane's refusal to agree with Jackson's intent to withdraw public money from bank.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Farewell letter to Donelson. Mentions dissapointment with Donelson in avoiding seeing him in person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains why he was unable to meet with Duane. Mentions Jackson's lack of enmity towards Duane, regret concerning turn of events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Duane for "friendly letter." Clarifies his position (denies) regarding press reporting his establishment of extra-constitutional bureau with the Treasury dept.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.

did.unittitle: Opinions regarding Bank of the United States

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes R. B. Taney's opinion of deposit question.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. Hand transcribed opinions copied from newspapers and other sources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of support, regarding Duane's stance in the Bank of the United States matter.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. A copy of Duane's response is on same letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks citizens of Loudon county for their support.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. Hand transcribed copy on original from Nixon from 1834 Jan. 16.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of support.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declines official portrait as member (former) of Jackson's cabinent. Claims a portrait reflects a conceited nature.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old catalog number Misc. Ms. Coll.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Gordon and citizens of his county for their sentiments. Mentions Jackson in less than flattering terms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of support from the Union Committee of Lancaster, PA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes to the Commercial Intellingencer, disputing the offical account of the Bank of the United States affair printed in the "President's official paper," the Globe.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. Includes clipping from The Globe (newspaper).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Union Committee of Lancaster, PA. For their letter of support on the 26th.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Mechanics of the city of Troy, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of support, re: Bank of the United States.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. Includes clipping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for a copy of a pamphlet. Salutes Duane for his sense of duty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of support from the citizens of Portage County, Ohio.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.1. 1974 1471ms. Includes clipping of Duane's response.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family and society news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business (legal) matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mentions Taney's confirmation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business (legal) correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to send Duane the minority report from congress?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses signature of Stephen Girard, along with testimonial as to Girard's character.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old call number B:D852.3. Includes clipping of Duane's obituary from 1863.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses packet of six letters originally from the President (June 26-Sept. 21, 1833).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Political news. Mentions Forward halting a publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes to the Secretary of the Treasury requesting a letter left behind in a larger packet of letters at the Treasury from his (Duane's) tenure as Secretary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of his trip to Illinois. Mentions local geography, potential for building wealth. Asks for a tailor to make him some work pants.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business (legal) correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that Duane sell his Race steet lot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt of a manuscript, "Accounts of the Overseerers of the Poor of the City of Philadelphia from March 29, 1758 to March 21, 1759." Transcribed from original by Duane. Officiating historical society officer: Peter Du Ponceau.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presents F. Hoskins paper on navigation, which was dedicated to Thomas Jefferson, to the American Philosophical Society.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old catalog number Misc. Ms. Coll. Unlocated as of 11/28/07.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of letter received on the fourth. Praises Duane's Journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dinner invitation

did.unittitle: ALS to James Buchanan and William S. Ramsay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Application on behalf of William Duane for the position of Visitor to the Military Academy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns disposition of Stephen Girard's will.

did.unittitle: Marriage contract between George V. Huddleston and Hannah C. Brackenridge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Marriage contract which names Duane as executor named to be in charge of all assets (estate in trust) of Brackenridge received from George Bartram's estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns national politics. Enjoyed his publication on education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Response to query concerning politicians descendents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family news. Mentions Charles Wall, Senior Fellow of Dublin College. Would like ring as token of friendship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comments on Duane's journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note (thanks) accompanying return of one of Duane's books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Duane for use of map. Concerning the Louisiana purchase and Texas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: States difficulty of obtaining book Duane desires. Refers to Edgar Allen Poe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of reccomendation for a John Towsend for a position in Customs Department.

did.unittitle: AQS, a fair copy, to Rev. Charles Hodge

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

acqinfo.p: Typescript presented by Whitfield J. Bell, from original in possession of Miss S.M. Hodge, Oct. 1957.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns the papers of Benjamin Franklin and the Bache family.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old catalog number Misc. Ms. Coll. Unlocated as of 11/28/07.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of Duane's son (Richard Bache Duane) visit to Clommel (Ireland). Political and social climate in Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promises aid in helping Duane, will see President (Tyler) regarding same.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires that only male relatives and male close friends attend her funeral.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a copy of an address given by Duane before the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement and thanks for a copy of a Franklin letter. Mentions Duane's interest in Pennsylvania history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of copy of Historical Society publication. Mentions Duane's interest in Congressional action regarding Native Americans.

did.unittitle: Deed: Philadelphia property belonging to William Duane (1807-1882)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges debt to Society?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note accompanying and acknowledging payment of subscription to the Seventy Six Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note accompanying and acknowledging payment of subscription to the Seventy Six Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses copies of two letters from John Dickinson to Arthur Lee--1774 August 20, and 22nd. Concerning Arthur Lee and Silas Deane. For encs., see: John Dickinson to A.Lee; Aug. 20, 1774, and Oct. 27, 1774.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of "friend Balch's" ill health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Duane for editing his work. Concerning a book on Franklin and some supposed "unpleasantness" to his "grandfather [R.Bache?]." Refers to Andrew Jackson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for picture to be delivered. [Possibly the B.Franklin picture which belonged to C. W. Bache.]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Old catalog number Misc. Ms. Coll.

scopecontent.p: Duane signs receipt on behalf of Catherine W. Bache.

did.unittitle: Toasts...Delegates to the Quarantine and Sanitary Convention

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Details items left behind to be disposed of.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fond recollections of sisters (now disceased). Contains instructions to forward a collection of family correspondence (not enclosed) to his grandson, Russell. Also contains a table of contents of correspondence (with no letters).

did.unittitle: Menu for Banquet : Fourth National Quarantine and Sanitary Convention

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Responds to letter received on the 24th. Mentions beginning work on Benjamin Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Responds to letter of 26th of prior month. Recalls his trip to Clonnel, Ireland in his youth. Mentions national political crisis (impending civil war), "At the very moment at which I am writing, I may say, the crisis is about to be breached."

did.physdesc: 1 pg. Printed L.filled in in ms.S.: Edward Everett and Edward Capen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Donated Franklin correspondence circa era 1779.

odd.p: Old call number B:D852. Printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received dispatches, requests information as to continuing situation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets. Will not be able to meet at time agreed on.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets late acknowledgement of letter. Mentions suffering from the "most bitter affliction of my life," his wife's impending death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of editing of first portion of book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for editing book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns a book on Franklin. Needs a picture of Deborah Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his wife's silverware to grandson, along with a copies of the works of Benjamin Franklin originally given to William John's mother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for consent of marriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Stock certificate, Mercantile Library Company of Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: $10.00 share.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of the Commissioners of Fairmont Park report.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clarifies genealogy of mutual acquaintances. Mentions that the son of one of their friends was killed two years ago with the 7th cavalry. Mentions work on life of Philip Schulyer. Refers to James Madison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to visit home in London. Mentions receipt of Philadelphia Park Report (1871).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comments on recent election and Republican politics In Pennsylvania and Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Confirms cannon transfer to new diocese in New Jersey. Welcomes Duane back to area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for sending pamphlet on names.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends address, review of a book. Requests a copy of Duane's latest book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Queries into Duane's knowledge of various known personages in New York and Philadelphia. Mentions desire to travel to Philadelphia next year. Encloses copy of a letter from him to a Theodore Ledyard Cuyler 1875 February 10.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report of a requested audit of Col. William Duane (his grandfather, editor of the Aurora), dept. of the Army. Mentions $2,397.22 due Duane senior, paid out on may 17, 1824.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement and thanks for copy of "Extracts from the diary of Christopher Marshall."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family genealogy inquiry, descendents of William Temple Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Responds to editorial criticism, rebuts most of Duane's suggestions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Confirms Duane's leaving current post as pastor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Directs release of funds and an assistant pastor to aid in "missionary work" by church volunteers in and around Jenkintown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Responds to query from Duane. States that it is a mistake for candidates for the ministry to marry, as it proves a distraction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice of obligatory diocese meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges acquaintance with individual Duane previously asked about. Gives testimonial to character of man in question.

scopecontent.p: Comments on matter concerning Board of Trustees of Massachusetts General Hospital.

scopecontent.p: Disposition of church collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of material sent. Mentions upcoming meeting.
